name: Coble
comment info:
1. I notice that more graduate students take online courses full-time when compared to other college levels, but most of the data for all college students was centered around a mix of both online and on-campus.  The data mimics that of a normal distribution which is surprising to me because I would think since COVID and the adaptations we had to do for online learning would sway the data that way.

2. I suppose there is no way to truly know, but I’m curious how many students would have chosen online learning if the pandemic hadn’t occurred.  Are they only choosing online learning because they became used to it or are there other underlying factors?

3. Many of our students still take courses at the physical campus because we only live an hour away from the more popular schools – Minot State & BSC.  There are still a few who take online courses so they can still work on their family’s ranch/farm.  As for adult learners, they take online courses because they need to work and/raise their family.  Personally speaking, I wouldn’t be able to work full-time and travel to the campus and I’m only taking one course.

4. “Is On-Campus Learning A Thing of the Past?”

name: Sandra
comment info:
What do I notice?
According to these officers, a very small percentage of students, regardless of level, will be fully on-campus. The highest percentage for fully on-campus was 4% for traditional-aged undergraduates, a very small number. 
There also appears to be a statistically significant difference between the projected percentages for the different types of students, suggesting that there is an association between the type of student (traditional-aged undergraduates, adult undergraduates, and graduate students) and how the student is expected to experience college. 
Furthermore, it appears that traditional-aged undergraduates are the more likely to experiences college on-campus, as the percentage of this group projected to be fully on-campus, majority on-campus, and a balance of campus/online are all greater than those percentages for the other groups, while the percentages for majority online, some on-campus and fully online are both the lowest out of all the groups. Potentially, this could be because traditional-aged undergraduates do not, generally, have full-time jobs and other outside commitments that would prevent them from attending school physically. 
I also notice that this study is limited by nonresponse bias, as only 271 responses were received from a total attempted sample of 4,700, and these people, who were willing to respond, likely have stronger or differing opinions from those who did not respond.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's live moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s graph displays a prediction by college online officers of how they think their students will be learning – in-person, online or a hybrid, in 2025.  Note the source of the data.  Also, “traditional-aged undergraduates” are students less than 25-years old. 

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?”, “What do you wonder?"  and “How will this affect you?”  Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas in these graphs. We look forward to replying to your discoveries.

By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the online article that included these graphs.  

Note that you can get a link to your response (and replies made to it) to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  

Please visit our archive to see all graphs in this series (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphs).
View our archives that link to all past releases, organized by topic (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTopicIndex), 
graph type (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTypeIndex) and 
Stat Nugget (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsStatNuggetsIndex).  

There will be no “What’s Going On In This Graph?” next week.  The next graph will be released by Friday, January 27 with moderation on Wednesday, February 1.
